author: Alison Bowen
title: One Simple Thing: A test for student-athletes' brains before, after concussions - Chicago
text:
Fall brings a season of high school athletes getting tackled and making headers.
Taking the time to get a student-athlete a quick brain test can be a simple way to monitor consequences of any concussions they get, one doctor says.
Known as a baseline test, the computerized test can be taken in about 30 minutes, said Dr. Joseph Rempson, co-director of the Center for Concussion Care and Physical Rehabilitation at Overlook Medical Center's Neuroscience Institute in Summit, N.J.
The test measures different aspects of brain responsiveness, like reaction time or memory.
Rempson, who often works to educate athletic departments on head injuries, cautioned that this is only one part of monitoring concussions.
"Sometimes parents believe that this is definitive," he said. "It's really a tiny piece of it."
He added, "It only measures one small aspect of brain functioning. (For example), many kids with concussions have headaches. It doesn't measure the headache. It doesn't measure dizziness."
The test is ideally taken before a season starts, but even midseason, absent any concussive incidents, Rempson recommends that parents bring a student in.
"You're in effect taking a test to basically see, when you're healthy, how you score," he said. After a concussion or something similar, he said, "you're retesting to see if certain aspects of that change."
And even after recovery, "We retest them to see if things have gone back to the way they were before the injury."
Rempson said parents in many locations should be able to find someone to facilitate the test .
Ideally, that time with a doctor also will include a bit of information about what a concussion is and how it's managed and treated, he added.
He recommends these tests starting at age 10, before every season, and every one or two years following.
